official-title.#text: To improve the accountability and transparency of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, and for other purposes.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Federal Reserve Accountability and Transparency Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Federal Reserve Accountability and Transparency Act of 2014

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: the following:
is amended by inserting after

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Section 11 of the Federal Reserve Act

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall—
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System

text.#text: Before issuing any regulation, the

clearly identify the nature and source of the problem that the proposed regulation is designed to address, as well as assess the significance of that problem, to enable assessment of whether any new regulation is warranted;

assess the costs and benefits, both qualitative and quantitative, of the intended regulation and propose or adopt a regulation only on a reasoned determination that the benefits of the intended regulation outweigh the costs of the regulation;

identify and assess available alternatives to the regulation that were considered, including modification of an existing regulation, together with an explanation of why the regulation meets the regulatory objectives more effectively than the alternatives; and
ensure that any regulation is accessible, consistent, written in plain language, and easy to understand and shall measure, and seek to improve, the actual results of regulatory requirements.

evaluate whether, consistent with obtaining regulatory objectives, the regulation is tailored to impose the least burden on society, including market participants, individuals, businesses of differing sizes, and other entities (including State and local governmental entities), taking into account, to the extent practicable, the cumulative costs of regulations; and
evaluate whether the regulation is inconsistent, incompatible, or duplicative of other Federal regulations.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall assess the costs and benefits of available regulatory alternatives, including the alternative of not regulating, and choose the approach that maximizes net benefits. Specifically, the
shall—

text.#text: In deciding whether and how to regulate, the
investor choice;
market liquidity in the securities markets;
small businesses;
economic growth;
cost and access to capital;
market stability;
global competitiveness;
job creation;
rate of inflation; and
employment levels.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall, to the extent that each is relevant to the particular proposed regulation, take into consideration the impact of the regulation on—

text.#text: In addition, in making a reasoned determination of the costs and benefits of a potential regulation, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall explain in its final rule the nature of comments that it received, including those from the industry or consumer groups concerning the potential costs or benefits of the proposed rule or proposed rule change, and shall provide a response to those comments in its final rule, including an explanation of any changes that were made in response to those comments and the reasons that the
did not incorporate those industry group concerns related to the potential costs or benefits in the final rule.

The purposes and intended consequences of the regulation.

text.#text: Whenever the

The assessment plan required under this paragraph shall consider the costs, benefits, and intended and unintended consequences of the regulation. The plan shall specify the data to be collected, the methods for collection and analysis of the data and a date for completion of the assessment. The assessment plan shall include an analysis of any jobs added or lost as a result of the regulation, differentiating between public and private sector jobs.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall, not later than 2 years after the publication of the adopting release, cause the assessment report to be published in the Federal Register for notice and comment. If the
determines, at least 90 days before such date, that an extension is necessary, the

shall publish a notice of such extension in the Federal Register, along with the specific reasons why the extension is necessary. Any material modification of the plan, as necessary to assess unforeseen aspects or consequences of the regulation, shall be promptly published in the Federal Register for notice and comment.

If, at the time of any appearance described in this paragraph, the position of Vice Chairman for Supervision is vacant, the Vice Chairman for the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System (who has the responsibility to serve in the absence of the Chairman) shall appear instead and provide the required written testimony. header.#text: Designation of chairman and deputy chairman

text.#text: by amending the twenty-fourth undesignated paragraph to read as follows:
with respect to the four class A directors, one director’s term shall expire in each of the first and second years and two directors’ terms shall expire in the third year; and
with respect to the five class B directors, one director’s term shall expire in the first year and two directors’ terms shall expire in each of the second and third years.
Every director of a Federal reserve bank shall hold office for a term of three years, and such terms shall be staggered, from the date of the enactment of this paragraph, such that—

Vacancies that may occur in the several classes of directors of Federal reserve banks may be filled in the manner provided for the original selection of such directors, such appointees to hold office for the unexpired terms of their predecessors.

header.#text: Improvements to the Financial Institutions Examination Council

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is amended by adding at the end the following:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Section 1008 of the Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council Act of 1978
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council Act of 1978/s:1008

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall—

text.#text: Before issuing any regulation, the

clearly identify the nature and source of the problem that the proposed regulation is designed to address, as well as assess the significance of that problem, to enable assessment of whether any new regulation is warranted;

assess the costs and benefits, both qualitative and quantitative, of the intended regulation and propose or adopt a regulation only on a reasoned determination that the benefits of the intended regulation outweigh the costs of the regulation;

identify and assess available alternatives to the regulation that were considered, including modification of an existing regulation, together with an explanation of why the regulation meets the regulatory objectives more effectively than the alternatives; and
ensure that any regulation is accessible, consistent, written in plain language, and easy to understand and shall measure, and seek to improve, the actual results of regulatory requirements.

evaluate whether, consistent with obtaining regulatory objectives, the regulation is tailored to impose the least burden on society, including market participants, individuals, businesses of differing sizes, and other entities (including State and local governmental entities), taking into account, to the extent practicable, the cumulative costs of regulations; and
evaluate whether the regulation is inconsistent, incompatible, or duplicative of other Federal regulations.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall assess the costs and benefits of available regulatory alternatives, including the alternative of not regulating, and choose the approach that maximizes net benefits. Specifically, the
shall—

text.#text: In deciding whether and how to regulate, the
investor choice;
market liquidity in the securities markets;
small businesses;
economic growth;
cost and access to capital;
market stability;
global competitiveness;
job creation;
rate of inflation; and
employment levels.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall, to the extent that each is relevant to the particular proposed regulation, take into consideration the impact of the regulation on—

text.#text: In addition, in making a reasoned determination of the costs and benefits of a potential regulation, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall explain in its final rule the nature of comments that it received, including those from the industry or consumer groups concerning the potential costs or benefits of the proposed rule or proposed rule change, and shall provide a response to those comments in its final rule, including an explanation of any changes that were made in response to those comments and the reasons that the
did not incorporate those industry group concerns related to the potential costs or benefits in the final rule.

text.#text: The
The purposes and intended consequences of the regulation.

Appropriate post-implementation quantitative and qualitative metrics to measure the economic impact of the regulation and to measure the extent to which the regulation has accomplished the stated purposes.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , to assess whether the regulation has achieved the stated purposes.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council Act of 1978/s:1008/ss:d/p:4/sp:B

text.#text: The assessment plan that will be used, consistent with the requirements of
Any reasonably foreseeable indirect effects that may result from the regulation.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: adopts or amends a regulation designated as a
, it shall state, in its adopting release, the following:

text.#text: Whenever the

The assessment plan required under this paragraph shall consider the costs, benefits, and intended and unintended consequences of the regulation. The plan shall specify the data to be collected, the methods for collection and analysis of the data and a date for completion of the assessment. The assessment plan shall include an analysis of any jobs added or lost as a result of the regulation, differentiating between public and private sector jobs.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall, not later than 2 years after the publication of the adopting release, cause the assessment report to be published in the Federal Register for notice and comment. If the
determines, at least 90 days before such date, that an extension is necessary, the

shall public a notice of such extension in the Federal Register, along with the specific reasons why the extension is necessary. Any material modification of the plan, as necessary to assess unforeseen aspects or consequences of the regulation, shall be promptly published in the Federal Register for notice and comment.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: has published its assessment plan for notice and comment, specifying the data to be collected and method of collection, at least 30 days prior to adoption of a final regulation or amendment, such collection of data shall not be subject to the notice and comment requirements in
has published notice for comment in the Federal Register of the additional data to be collected, at least 30 days prior to initiation of data collection.

text.#text: If the

(commonly referred to as the

has determined that no action will be taken on the regulation. Such a notice will be deemed a final agency action.

text.#text: Not later than 180 days after publication of the assessment report in the Federal Register, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , including rules, orders of general applicability, interpretive releases, and other statements of general applicability that the
intends to have the force and effect of law; and

text.#text: means a statement of general applicability and future effect that is designed to implement, interpret, or prescribe law or policy or to describe the procedure or practice requirements of the
does not include—

a regulation that is limited to the organization, management, or personnel matters of the
a regulation promulgated pursuant to statutory authority that expressly prohibits compliance with this provision; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: to be an emergency action, if such certification is published in the Federal Register.

external-xref.#tail: of title 5, Code of Federal Regulations, to the same extent as such provisions apply to an employee of the

header.#text: Prohibited and restricted financial interests and transactions
Treatment of brokerage accounts and availability of account statements

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall—

text.#text: The members and employees of the

disclose all brokerage accounts that they maintain, as well as those in which they control trading or have a financial interest (including managed accounts, trust accounts, investment club accounts, and the accounts of spouses or minor children who live with the member or employee); and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , authorize their brokers and dealers to send duplicate account statements directly to Council.

text.#text: with respect to any securities account that the member or employee is required to disclose to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall be subject to the prohibitions related to outside employment and activities described under

text.#text: The members and employees of the

external-xref.#tail: of title 5, Code of Federal Regulations, to the same extent as such prohibitions apply to an employee of the

header.#text: Prohibitions related to outside employment and activities

text.#text: The members and employees of the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: under part 735 of title 5, Code of Federal Regulations;

text.#text: the employee responsibilities and conduct regulations of the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: ; and

text.#text: the canons of ethics contained in subpart C of part 200 of title 17, Code of Federal Regulations, to the same extent as such subpart applies to the employees of the

the regulations concerning the conduct of members and employees and former members and employees contained in subpart M of part 200 of title 17, Code of Federal Regulations, to the same extent as such subpart applies to the employees of the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall be deemed a public filer if the employee is an attorney, accountant, examiner, auditor, investigator, or deals with information technology security.

text.#text: For purposes of the financial disclosure requirements under part 2634 of title 5, Code of Federal Regulations, an employee of the

header.#text: Additional employees required To make a public financial disclosure

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall make publicly available, on the website of the
, a searchable database that contains the names of all Members and employees of the
, and—

text.#text: The

header.#text: Disclosure of staff salaries and financial information

text.#text: the yearly salary information for such individuals, along with any non-salary compensation received by such individuals; and
any financial disclosures required to be made by such individuals.
